author: Anja van Oosterhout
headertext: Bitcoin Futures Record Volume Reflects ‚ÄòIncremental‚Äô Institutional Demand
subheaders: ['CMEs Half-Billion Dollar Bitcoin Market', 'Time Is Right For Institutions And BTC', 'Crypto Regulation Shake-Up Awaits']
contenttext: Anja van Oosterhout | Jun 13, 2019 | 06:00 Record Bitcoin futures volume in May is leading mainstream media to determine that Bitcoin is becoming a mature financial asset class. As Blockchain investor Oliver Isaacs noted June 13, CME Group‚Äôs Bitcoin futures set new records for both volume and open interest last month.  A total of $515 million in notional value was traded, a surge of more than a third since April and 250 percent more year on year. This, Reuters reported citing various crypto business‚Äô performance, is further proof Bitcoin‚Äôs 2019 renaissance has transformed perceptions of a market which held little faith even six months ago. The largest cryptocurrency is ‚Äúgrowing up,‚Äù says the publication, quoting the record volume in CME Group‚Äôs BTC futures market.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs logical they (institutional investors) would want to be moving in this direction, especially considering their size and how much more there is at stake,‚Äù Joel Kruger, currency strategist at LMAX Exchange Group added accompanying comments.  Tom Lee, co-founder of Fundstrat Global Advisors, was similarly buoyed by the futures data. ‚ÄúThis is very bullish as‚Ä¶ the rise in (Bitcoin) futures volume reflects incremental institutional money,‚Äù he wrote on Twitter.  As Bitcoinist frequently noted in recent weeks, the Bitcoin network‚Äôs fundamental metrics are combining to give the impression the current price strengthening is more reliable than any previous bull run.  Optimists hope that the advances seen in April and May are the tip of an iceberg which researchers identify as a new phase in Bitcoin‚Äôs history ‚Äì one that could even take it to supremacy over fiat competitors such as Visa and MasterCard. For institutional investors wanting in on BTC, however, this year‚Äôs increasing entry was down to regulatory changes accompanying a price uptick, Sui Chung, head of cryptocurrency pricing products at Crypto Facilities said.  ‚ÄúThis is the first time those stars have aligned,‚Äù he told Reuters.  Yet the picture is not entirely rosy. As Bitcoinist reported, further upcoming regulatory hurdles could soon put the brakes on investor enthusiasm. The dampener comes in the form of the Financial Action Task Force (FATF), which has pledged to publish its cryptocurrency recommendations for 200 countries later this month.  Criticized as ill thought out and even ‚Äúabsurd,‚Äù the guidance will aim to treat exchanges and associated businesses in an identical way to banks, despite the chalk-and-cheese differences between banking and Bitcoin transactions. In an ironically timely move, CBOE, the first entity to offer Bitcoin futures trading in December 2017, will wind down its operations entirely when its last contracts expire in June.  What do you think about Bitcoin futures performance? Let us know in the comments below! Images via Twitter, Shutterstock

author: Osato Avan-Nomayo
headertext: ‚ÄòUltra-Bull Case‚Äô for Bitcoin Driven By Central Banks ‚Äì Anthony Pompliano
subheaders: ['A Perfect Storm for Bitcoin', 'Era Defining Moment for BTC']
contenttext: Osato Avan-Nomayo ¬∑  @3rdPesinSingula | Jun 12, 2019 | 15:00 Anthony ‚ÄòPomp‚Äô Pompliano of Morgan Creek Digital believes Bitcoin is about to experience an epoch-defining next 18 months. Speaking to Bloxlive TV earlier in June, Pompliano said the next 18 months will be crucial for Bitcoin. The Morgan Creek Digital co-founder believes the plethora of developments with potentially global economic impacts will contribute to upscaling Bitcoin‚Äôs role in the global financial system. Will Bitcoin Reign as King in Times of Economic Instability? @APompliano shares his thoughts with @BloxliveTV https://t.co/0eTl8nhm1z pic.twitter.com/s0nBvqLhde ‚Äî Jessica Walker üé¨üöÄ (@Jessicaw_tv) June 11, 2019  Pomp drew a line linking trade tensions between the U.S. and China, dovish central bank policies and the 2020 Bitcoin halving as important drivers that will have a positive impact on BTC price. According to Pompliano: Over the next 12 to 18 months, we are going get a perfect storm for bitcoin. There are a number of events that are going to happen at the same time. Central banks will be forced into some interest rate cuts, maybe some QE. These events [will] ultimately drive Bitcoin into an ultra-bull case. Already, several market analysts warn that the current global economic trajectory is one tending towards another financial crisis. Bitcoin appears to be in prime position to ride this tumultuous economic wave, offering, as Bitcoinist¬†called it in an op-ed late last year, ‚Äúa non-political alternative to the money printing pyramid.‚Äù Monetary policymakers around the world from the Federal Reserve in the U.S. to the Bank of Japan (BOJ), and the European Central Bank (ECB) are all adopting dovish policies. There are reports of adopting rate cuts or even zero-interest-rate policy (ZIRP), not to mention the seemingly permanent quantitative easing used to paper over the cracks of a deteriorating market. Bitcoin emerged after the 2008 financial crisis and the next year-and-a-half could potentially form its defining crucible. This ‚Äòdigital gold‚Äô is already providing a suitable shelter for investors against the coming financial storm. Ironically, it is the banks themselves that could further solidify its status as the prime driver in the separation of money and state.  If the separation of church and state opened the way for religious and political freedom, Bitcoin proponents argue that a politically-neutral, opt-in monetary system could do the same for economic freedom. In other words, it can do to money what the internet did for information. Bitcoin in many ways has the ability to ‚Äòscale trust‚Äô in society by completely removing it from the equation. This will be particularly important when it comes to transferring and storing value compared to the ‚Äòfull faith and credit‚Äô fiat money that has been holding the global financial system hostage. Bitcoin will hopefully be a fully realized store of value when, not if, the credit bubble inevitably bursts. What is your bitcoin price prediction for the year ending 2020? Let us know in the comments below.

author: Anja van Oosterhout
headertext: ‚ÄòTotally Absurd‚Äô ‚Äì New FATF Rules To Turn Bitcoin Exchanges Into Banks
subheaders: ['FATF Among Biggest Threats To Crypto', 'Exchanging Over $1k? Provide Absurd Evidence']
contenttext: Anja van Oosterhout | Jun 12, 2019 | 13:00 Intergovernmental body the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) has committed to making 200 countries treat cryptocurrency exchanges like banks. As Bloomberg reported June 11, an update to how national regulators should treat businesses dealing with cryptocurrency tokens will officially go public on the 21st of the month.  Its impact is not entirely clear, but experts are already warning that anyone ‚Äì be it a business or a private investor ‚Äì who exchanges more than $B1000 or ‚Ç¨1000 worth of crypto will have to provide personal information.  For businesses such as exchanges and asset managers, the requirements stipulate the recipient of funds must also be identified ‚Äì something many have insisted is impossible with decentralized cryptocurrencies.  The FATF can only make ‚Äòrecommendations,‚Äô and their application is a matter for each jurisdiction‚Äôs authorities. Those countries which do not comply can face blacklisting, however, and even removal from the global financial system. ‚ÄúTheir recommendation could have a much larger impact than the SEC or any other regulator has had to date,‚Äù Eric Turner, director of research at crypto research firm Messari, told Bloomberg about the potential changes in the US. Turner added the issue was ‚Äúone of the biggest threats to crypto today.‚Äù As Bitcoinist reported, the FATF announced an incremental approach to cryptocurrency management in October last year.  ‚ÄúAs part of a staged approach, the FATF will prepare updated guidance on a risk-based approach to regulating virtual asset service providers, including their supervision and monitoring; and guidance for operational and law enforcement authorities on identifying and investigating illicit activity involving virtual assets,‚Äù its president, Marshall Billingslea, said at the time. ‚Äú‚Ä¶By June, we will issue additional instructions on the standards and how we expect them to be enforced.‚Äù Two months later, G20 members pledged to implement the organization‚Äôs suggestions in full, a stance it repeated this month.  As the deadline approached, cryptocurrency figures were already sounding the alarm, noting the apparent ineptitude on the part of FATF bureaucrats attempting to apply banking rules to Bitcoin 00 and others.  ‚ÄúThe people trying to understand Bitcoin are not consulting with anyone who actually understands it and who can put it into a proper context,‚Äù Azteco CEO, Akin Fernandez, commented on Twitter in May.  Uploading an image of how a Bitcoin transaction contrasts with a bank-to-bank one, he added: Bitcoin is not a bank. It is not SWIFT. It is not money. It is just a database. When you accept this, the above image looks totally absurd. What do you think about the FATF‚Äôs new recommendations? Let us know in the comments below!

author: Emilio Janus
headertext: Miss Hong Kong Explains ‚ÄòBitcoin Time Traveler‚Äô On Biggest TV Channel
subheaders: ['Explaining The Bitcoin Time-Traveler Theory', 'But Thats Just Another Crazy Conspiracy Theory', 'So, $100k Price Target For 2019?']
contenttext: Emilio Janus | Jun 12, 2019 | 11:00 The winner of the Miss Hong Kong 2015 pageant has appeared on the territory‚Äôs most popular TV channel explaining the ‚ÄòBitcoin Time Traveler‚Äô theory. The theory stems from a Reddit post made in 2013, by a user named Luke Magnotta. In it, he claimed to be a time traveler from the year 2025 and gave a detailed description of how Bitcoin had created a political dystopia. Part of the post detailed the rise in bitcoin price up until 2013, and how it would continue to rise in the future. Essentially it stated that the approximate tenfold increases each year would slow down to occur every two years. So the sequence of $0.1 ‚Äì 2010, $1 ‚Äì 2011, $10 ‚Äì 2012, $100 ‚Äì 2013, would continue as follows: $1000 in 2015, $10,000 in 2017, $100,000 in 2019, and $1 million in 2021. Well, that‚Äôs what most believe, and that was certainly the theme of (at least) that segment of the show. Of of the other panelists explained the Avril Lavigne conspiracy theory; that she didn‚Äôt just sell-out her skate-punk roots, but instead died in 2003, and was replaced by a more pop-friendly double.  But it has recently gained media attention again, with certain groups suggesting that the prediction is coming true. I mean, it demonstrably isn‚Äôt true, as bitcoin price crossed the $100 mark and hit $1000 in 2013, just a few months after the post was made. But bear with me‚Ä¶ In very general terms, if you squint your eyes a bit, and just glance at it momentarily. Ignoring obvious bubbles, bitcoin securely passed the $1000 hurdle on 2nd January 2016. That‚Äôs very almost 2015. And bitcoin certainly crossed the $10,000 mark in 2017‚Ä¶ if we consider 2018 to be an over-correction and $10k to be an inherent value. Critics of the ‚ÄòBitcoin Time Traveler‚Äô theory point out that, if a time traveler had actual knowledge, would he not give exact prices rather than a rough schematic of gains. Which is a fair enough point. However, potential self-cannibalist, John McAfee, sees it as some form of vilification. In a recent tweet, he drew attention to the story, noting that 2021 is just one day away from his predicted $1 million bitcoin date of 31st December 2020. I'm not the only madman in crypto apparently. $1 mil prediction by 2021 by the man who has never been wrong in his predictions.. 2021 us just one day away from my prediction  of $1 mil by 12/31/2020.https://t.co/9dafiU4P9R ‚Äî John McAfee (@officialmcafee) May 28, 2019  Mind you, in 2021 the dollar apparently isn‚Äôt used any more, so maybe it‚Äôs a moot point? So, could Luke Magnotta be a real time-traveler? Is he really here to save us from a future they intend to nuke (as the original post goes on to claim)? Or is this just some early FUD, potentially created by a forward-looking central bank already running scared? I guess we just wait and see. What do you think about the Bitcoin time traveler theory? Add your thoughts below!

author: Anja van Oosterhout
headertext: Cash Is King In Hong Kong As Thousands Choose Financial Privacy
subheaders: ['Hong Kong Pays Cash To Avoid Tracking', 'A Perfect Storm For Bitcoin?']
contenttext: Anja van Oosterhout | Jun 12, 2019 | 05:00 Hong Kong is waking up to the benefits of financial privacy using cash, reports claim, as protesters seek to hide their movements and identity. According to various reports surfacing on social media this week, participants in the ongoing rallies against the Hong Kong government are choosing to abandon payment methods which could track them. A planned law dubbed the ‚ÄòExtradition Bill‚Äô wants to make it possible to send suspects to mainland China. This, the protesters say, would open up Hong Kong‚Äôs legal system to manipulation and for Beijing. Fresh from the 2014 ‚ÄòUmbrella Movement‚Äô pro-democracy events, citizens are now all too aware of the need to protect their identity in the face of a government with an increasing reputation for surveillance and intrusion.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre afraid of having our data tracked,‚Äù a female protester told QZ reporter Mary Hui. Hui was at a metro station in Hong Kong and noticed long lines at ticket machines ‚Äústretching back 10+ meters.‚Äù There is usually never a line at the train ticketing machines. Judging from an overheard convo, it appears that people are reluctant to use their rechargeable Octopus cards for fear of leaving a paper trail of them having been present at the protest. pic.twitter.com/s1rsgSnCqL ‚Äî Mary Hui (@maryhui) June 12, 2019  The machines are normally empty, she said, as passengers use rechargeable smartcards which can be topped up in various ways. Now, however, with 2014 still in their minds, they appreciate the need for privacy when it comes to money. ‚ÄúShe said that this ticket-buying (wasn‚Äôt) as prevalent during the 2014 Umbrella Movement. Five years on, however, people are more wary & aware,‚Äù Hui summarized on Twitter. As Bitcoinist has reported, multiple governments have declared a ‚Äòwar on cash‚Äô as part of efforts to standardize their countries‚Äô economies. While authorities say such measures reduce crime, opponents argue it leaves the door open to full control of the financial system and opportune intrusion into citizens‚Äô financial lives for any purpose. A recent case in point is India, where the central bank is actively pursuing a digitization plan which has already seen shambolic currency reform and widespread backlash from consumers.  Hong Kong, however, provides a rare example of broad public understanding of the benefits of cash and how states could use money to persecute. ‚ÄúThis raises a lot of interesting questions about cash vs. cashless societies, and how in times of protest people may drastically adjust their usual economic behavior,‚Äù Hui added. The protests predictably shook up the Hong Kong dollar (HKD), which has gained against the USD in recent days due to a liquidity squeeze sending investors long, Bloomberg reports.  The government has in fact spent $2.8 billion since March maintaining HKD‚Äôs peg with the USD, with concerns about financial policy compounded by the political events. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt trust China. Rules and laws can be arbitrarily applied and we can see this in Hong Kong already,‚Äù a protester told UK publication The Guardian, adding that should the Extradition Bill pass, he would immediately convert his savings to USD.  Bitcoin trade volumes meanwhile have shown a modest uptick on P2P platform Localbitcoins over the past several weeks. A local Bitcoin company has joined the protests and given all its employees the day off. #ExtraditionBill pic.twitter.com/AFWUuDDFWg ‚Äî Leo Weese ÁçÖËçâÂú∞ (@LeoAW) June 12, 2019  It should be noted that Hong Kong has the largest number of Bitcoin ATMs in Asia, while the local industry appears naturally supportive of the protests. One company, a Twitter user spotted, has closed in order to allow employees to march. What do you think about Hong Kong embracing cash? Let us know in the comments below!

author: Georgi Georgiev
headertext: Bitcoin Has Dwarfed Warren Buffet‚Äôs Berkshire Hathaway in ROI
subheaders: ['Berkshire Hathaway Up 997,900%', 'Bitcoin Up 720,000,000% in 10 Years', 'Facts Speak For Themselves']
contenttext: Georgi Georgiev | Jun 11, 2019 | 21:00 Warren Buffett‚Äôs Berkshire Hathaway has seen an impressive increase of around 997,900 percent in its stock price since Warren Buffett took control. Bitcoin, on the other hand, is up 720,000,000% in its short 10-year history since its first recorded price.¬† Berkshire Hathaway, a multinational conglomerate holding company, the CEO of which is no other but popular investor and one of the richest men alive, Warren Buffett, has seen an increase of 997,900 percent in its stock price since the prominent investor took control of it back in 1964. The company is also well-known for the fact that it has been under the leadership of one of the most well-known investors, Warren Buffett. He is currently the CEO at Berkshire Hathaway. Forbes‚Äô latest listicle of the richest men puts Buffett as the third wealthiest man with an estimated net worth of $82.5 billion. Bitcoin, on the other hand, has only been around in the past decade. However, in this relatively short amount of time, the cryptocurrency has managed to increase by a whopping 720,000,000 percent¬†since its first ever recorded price. Ironically, Buffett, being the prominent and well-known investor that he is, is a sworn Bitcoin-basher. In fact, Buffett has been particularly vocal on his stance on the matter, calling Bitcoin all sorts of things. Buffett said: It doesn‚Äôt do anything. It just sits there. It‚Äôs like a seashell or something, and that is not an investment to me. It‚Äôs a gambling device‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs been a lot of frauds connected with it. There‚Äôs been disappearances, so there‚Äôs a lot lost on it. Bitcoin hasn‚Äôt produced anything. If that‚Äôs not definitive enough, Buffett has also called the leading cryptocurrency ‚Äúrat poison squared.‚Äù Going even further, Buffett‚Äôs Berkshire Hathaway invested $340 into an alleged Ponzi-type scheme according to¬†Bloomberg. Federal investigators maintain that DC Solar, the company which received Buffett‚Äôs backing has used new investors‚Äô money to pay back existing investors. So if Buffett, the infallible investment genius that everyone seems to believe he is, failed to recognize a Fed-investigated Ponzi-scheme, could it be possible that he‚Äôs also wrong about Bitcoin? Regardless of whether Buffett likes it or not, this ‚Äúrat poison‚Äù has massively outperformed the company he controls. It‚Äôs also worth noting that Berkshire Hathaway wholly owns prominent corporations such as Geico, Duracell, Long & Foster, and so forth. It also controls minority shares at American Express, Wells Fargo, and The Coca-Cola Company. Bitcoin does none of the above and isn‚Äôt even a company with any central authority. It‚Äôs simply a decentralized protocol for money that ensures no one breaks the rule. Bitcoin is an asset class of its own that has managed to gain 722 times more money to its investors compared to Berkshire Hathaway. And it only took it 10 years. So, in case anyone doubts John McAfee in putting a $1 million price target for Bitcoin, it‚Äôs perhaps worth considering all of the above. Sure, it may not happen by December 31st, 2020, but it‚Äôs certainly a possibility. Maybe Buffett should reconsider. Though, perhaps Justin Sun is the one (not) to make him change his mind. What do you think of Bitcoin hitting $1 million? Do you think it will happen? Don‚Äôt hesitate to let us know in the comments below! Images courtesy of Shutterstock

author: Allen Scott
headertext: Top 3 Cryptocurrency Lending Platforms
subheaders: ['#1 Celsius Network ', '#2 INLOCK', '#3 BlockFi']
contenttext: Allen Scott ¬∑  @bitcoinister | Jun 11, 2019 | 18:00 Cryptocurrency lending services are seeing increasing demand and users. So who are the top crypto lending services today? Let‚Äôs take a look. Cryptocurrencies have gone a long way in their relatively short life span. In 10 years, their total market exceeds $254 billion having plunged from an all-time high upwards of $800 billion back in 2017. Moreover, they are also seeing increasingly widespread adoption as more and more traditional industry participants are beginning to accept them as a means of payment. Hence, the number of people who got involved in the industry throughout the past 10 years has grown substantially.  Naturally, this also brings forward a variety of related services, capturing the needs of the growing audience. Cryptocurrency lending is perhaps one of the most interesting fields to discuss as these services saw a serious spike in interest and profitability despite 2018‚Äôs prolonged bear market.  With this said, let‚Äôs have a look at the three of the best cryptocurrency platforms today.  Celsius Network is perhaps one of the most recognized cryptocurrency lending platforms on the market right now.  Back in 2018, its application saw 40,000 downloads, $50 million in coin deposits and paid out maximum interest of 7.1%.  It‚Äôs worth noting that Celsius Network shares up to 80% of its entire income with its community in the form of weekly interest payments. The way it works is fairly simple. Users can earn up to 10% are allowed to receive interest on their cryptocurrency holdings as soon as they deposit it in the Celsius Network wallets. There is no minimum deposit, no withdrawal fees, and no lockups. It‚Äôs as easy as that.  The official website features a comprehensive interest calculator which shows exactly how much interest the user will be able to earn on a weekly basis depending on how much they deposit.  Users can also apply for a USD or stablecoin loan using their cryptocurrency as collateral with rates as low as 4.95% APR.  The platform supports a broad range of different cryptocurrencies, including but not limited to Bitcoin, Ethereum, Litecoin, DASH, Ripple, and so forth.  INLOCK is another popular cryptocurrency lending platform where users are able to collateralize their holdings and take out a loan.  What‚Äôs interesting about INLOCK is that there is no centrally controlled interest rate. It operates under a peer-to-peer (P2P) model which ensures that the interest rates are determined by the dynamics of the supply and demand. What makes both parties safe is the fact that the borrower‚Äôs cryptocurrency backs up the loan entirely. This guarantees that the investment of the lender is perfectly safe.  Just as Celsius Network, INLOCK also provides the opportunity for users to offer their cryptocurrencies as loans and to receive interest on it.  BlockFi is another cryptocurrency lending platform which allows you to put your holdings to work. According to the official website, users can earn as much as 6.2% annually.  The website also reveals that the funding takes place on the same day through a stablecoin, or through a regular wire transfer. There is an available calculator which shows the interest rate users can expect to earn based on their deposit. BlockFi also provides home loans, auto loans, and the option to pay credit card debt with crypto-backed loans. Is lending becoming a vital service industry for crypto? Don‚Äôt hesitate to let us know in the comments below!

author: Ollie Leech
headertext: Bitcoin Price Shows Remarkable Correlation with Offshore RMB Futures
subheaders: ['What is the Offshore Renminbi Market Exactly? ', 'Bitcoin vs. Offshore RMB Futures Performance ', 'Correlation, Coincidence or Something More? ']
contenttext: Ollie Leech | Jun 11, 2019 | 15:00 Bitcoin‚Äôs price has seen a dramatic resurgence of bullish support over 2019, which has allowed it to decouple away from a vast majority of traditional financial markets. But when we compare its performance to the Offshore RMB Futures market, however, we can see a striking resemblance between the two trends. Let‚Äôs take a look. Renminbi (RMB) in Mandarin translates to ‚Äòthe people‚Äôs currency‚Äô, and has been officially recognized as the currency of the People‚Äôs Bank of China (PBoC) since 1948. The Chinese Yuan (CNY) is actually the unit of account for RMB and is not its own separate currency.   The Offshore Renminbi (RMB) market itself is a non-mainland China exchange setup originally in Hong Kong to facilitate extraterritorial trade with foreign countries. Since its inception 2003, three additional offshore RMB markets have cropped up in London, Singapore, and Taiwan.   But what‚Äôs the point? Well, by having a detached offshore market, China is able to keep its nation‚Äôs capital separate from foreign investments. This is important because not only does it safeguard the Chinese economy from recession if the world trade markets decline, but it also allows them to expand the reach of their currency to the global market.    Looking at the chart above, we can see the price performance of both Bitcoin (BTC) and the offshore RMB futures market over the last 8 months (blue and red lines respectively).   What‚Äôs surprising here, is that we can see a very clear correlation between the two trends despite both financial products ‚Äì if you can even class Bitcoin as a financial ‚Äòproduct‚Äô ‚Äì operating in two entirely different spheres.   When Bitcoin‚Äôs price 00 plummeted during the Bitcoin Cash ‚Äòhash war‚Äô in November last year, we can see that the offshore renminbi futures market followed the same steep downtrend almost exactly a month later.  Weird, right? The same similarity can be also seen when Bitcoin‚Äôs price made a strong recovery out of the bear market around April this year, only to be followed a month later by the RMB futures market again. What‚Äôs more, is that when we look at the most recent data on the chart, we can see that the RMB futures market now appears to have finally caught up with Bitcoin‚Äôs performance as both begin to correct at the exact same time.   What we can draw from this, is that it definitely seemed that Bitcoin was front running the offshore RMB market for a number of months. It could‚Äôve been that the two markets had become intrinsically linked because the vast majority of investors in the RMB futures market, were also trading in the BTC market ‚Äì which is quite possible given the popularity of Bitcoin across the Asian markets.   Once the Bitcoin market started to suffer in November, investors started to lose money. It‚Äôs likely that the bearish sentiment could‚Äôve seeped across into the offshore RMB futures market and caused investors to exit until the global markets stabilized.   The same can be said for when Bitcoin began to recover after the crash. The renewed bullish sentiment in the crypto market could very well have encouraged RMB futures traders to return to the market ‚Äì hence the spike in trades thereafter.   What do you think about this interesting correlation? Let‚Äôs us know in the comment section below!

author: Emilio Janus
headertext: Top 10 Biggest Cities Now Googling For ‚ÄòBitcoin‚Äô
subheaders: ['1. Lagos, Nigeria', '2. Vienna, Austria', '3. San Jose, California', '4. Los Angeles, California', '5. Toronto, Canada', '6-10. Munich, New York, Berlin, Singapore, Sydney', 'Top 10 Cities Googling Bitcoin Right Now']
contenttext: Emilio Janus | Jun 11, 2019 | 11:00 Bitcoin economist, Tuur Demeester, has been Googling Google for the cities where ‚ÄòBitcoin‚Äô was Googled the most. Thankfully, he tweeted the results on Twitter. The top city when it comes to interest in Bitcoin is Lagos. This should really come as no surprise. Nigeria has longstanding economic woes and has consistently been one of the top countries for Google searches. Use of Bitcoin as a hedge against rampant inflation is well documented.  Interestingly, adding ‚ÄòBuy‚Äô to make the search term ‚ÄòBuy Bitcoin‚Äô sees Lagos top the chart by an even greater margin. There were five times as many searches for ‚ÄòBuy Bitcoin‚Äô in Lagos than in the third-placed city, New York.  The only other city which comes close is second placed Accra in Ghana, with 73% of the searches in Lagos. So it seems like in Ghana, they want to buy bitcoin and don‚Äôt care what it is. Austria has long been punching above its weight in terms of ‚ÄòBitcoin‚Äô as a search term, and interest only seems to be increasing. The capital city, Vienna came second, with 70% of the number of searches from Lagos, though incredibly, with just over a tenth of the population. That means there were 7.3 times as many searches per capita in Vienna as in Lagos. Do the Viennese know something that we don‚Äôt? Now if I can just get that Ultravox song out of my head‚Ä¶ No surprises here either. San Jose is after all, where a lot of Silicon Valleys lives. What is perhaps more surprising is the diversity of these top 3 cities and the motivating factors that drive them to the top of Google trends. Oh, and of course I now have a different song in my head. Hollywood, Venice Beach, Bitcoin, and the Beach Boys. Of course, Los Angeles ranks highly. It‚Äôs very big. We might expect that to become a theme for the rest of the list. Canada‚Äôs most populous city and its champion of Google searches for ‚ÄòBitcoin‚Äô. CoinATMRadar lists 218 Bitcoin ATMs in and around the Toronto area. That‚Äôs more than twice as many as there are in Canada‚Äôs second largest city, Montreal. Munich saw Germany‚Äôs first legally sanctioned BATM installed just last year, and yet both Munich and Berlin feature in the top ten. The country‚Äôs interest clearly precedes its regulatory bodies. New Yorkers are possibly getting their searches in now, in fear that they may require a BitLicense to Google ‚ÄòBitcoin‚Äô in the future. The New York Post clearly isn‚Äôt managing to put them off. Singaporeans are so ahead of the curve that even their government invests in cryptocurrency, and the citizens of Sydney could just be checking where to spend their bitcoin on a kebab. So largely a list of major western cities, plus one major eastern city-state and one major African city. How do you interpret the data on where ‚ÄòBitcoin‚Äô is being Googled now? Add your thoughts below!

author: Anja van Oosterhout
headertext: South Korea‚Äôs Biggest Bank U-Turns on Crypto With Custody Service
subheaders: ['South Koreas Kookmin U-Turns on Crypto', 'Crypto, Blockchain Options On Radar', 'Worlds No.1 Insurer Inks Crypto Custody Insurance']
contenttext: Anja van Oosterhout | Jun 11, 2019 | 07:00 South Korea‚Äôs largest bank by assets, KB Kookmin, has partnered with a cryptocurrency startup to develop custody solutions. Reported by local media outlet Business Korea June 11, Kookmin will now work with local company Atomrigs Lab, which is active in digital asset protection.  The move marks a decisive change of tack for Kookmin, which until recently appeared to have a hands-off stance on cryptocurrency in general.  South Korea continues to be a hotspot for cryptocurrency activity in areas such as trading, with mixed regulatory signals failing to dampen consumer enthusiasm this year.  ‚ÄúWe hope that the two companies will grow together by discovering innovative services in the field of digital asset management with this agreement,‚Äù Lee Koo-il, CEO of Kookmin Bank, meanwhile commented after inking the partnership on Monday. We will expand the digital ecosystem through cooperation. The exact outcome of the joint development plans with Atomrigs remains less certain but incorporates a wide range of technologies associated with both cryptocurrency storage and Blockchain. According to Business Korea, the two will ‚Äújointly study digital asset protection technology and smart contract application methods‚Ä¶ and opted to actively explore new business opportunities in the field of digital assets.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThe company will also develop digital asset management services that combine Atomrigs Lab‚Äôs technology with Kookmin Bank‚Äôs internal control infrastructure and information protection technologies,‚Äù the publication continued.  In addition, the two companies have agreed to cooperate with each other in the creation of a bridge ecosystem between the blockchain network and finance. Last year, Kookmin had come under fire from South Korea regulators over its poor anti-money laundering procedures regarding transactions originating from cryptocurrency sources.  Worldwide, banks offering crypto custody solutions meanwhile looks set to become an ever-increasing trend.  Attempts thus far have taken various forms, such as Dutch lender ABN Amro‚Äôs in-house crypto wallet, which controversially stipulates the bank holds investors‚Äô private keys.  This week, the world‚Äôs second-larger insurer Metaco announced it was now offering crypto custody insurance via a deal with Aon.  ‚ÄúInsurance is an essential requirement for banking clients and METACO is excited to be able to facilitate insurance for our clients through the leading broker for crypto insurance solutions,‚Äù Metaco CEO and founder Adrien Treccani commented in an accompanying press release. As Bitcoinist reported, institutional investment in Bitcoin 00 and other cryptocurrencies are expected to constitute a major phenomenon in the coming years. In May, a survey by pro-crypto asset manager Fidelity Investments revealed half of investors considered crypto a worthy sector for their portfolio. What do you think about KB Kookmin Bank and Metaco‚Äôs moves? Let us know in the comments below!

author: Christina Comben
headertext: Female Engagement in Bitcoin Hits New High as Adoption Grows
subheaders: ['More Women in Bitcoin Shows Adoption Is Spreading', 'More Women in Leadership Positions', 'Bitcoin Is Gaining Mindshare and Thats What Counts']
contenttext: Christina Comben | Jun 11, 2019 | 06:00 Great news in terms of girl power and the growing number of women in Bitcoin. Female adoption is at an all-time high. Although, it‚Äôs still woefully dwarfed by men, who make up over 90%. The slice of the pie taken up by women may look a little measly at 9.1%. But, let‚Äôs celebrate the small victories. This time last year, women in Bitcoin made up just 3% of all users.  The times are definitely changing, despite the lengthy bear market. There may be less retail FOMO than 2017, but Bitcoin is now distinctly more than just a word thrown around at dinner parties.  Savvy females are finding use cases for it as a store of value, payment method, and alternative banking method. Sadly, 2018 saw a slight dip in women in leadership positions despite an all-time high in 2017, when they made up 6.4% of Fortune 500 CEOs.  However, despite this drop, there is a growing number of females present on Fortune 500 boards at over 22%. There are also plenty more key female figures leading up innovation teams, tech, blockchain policy, and speaking at major events. Ok, so spotting women at blockchain conferences can be like staking out near-extinct wildlife species in the jungle. But, it is slowly beginning to change. Rome wasn‚Äôt built in a day after all.  From long-term champions like Amber Baldet, Meltem Demirors, and BitGive‚Äôs Connie Gallippi to heavyweights like Lightning Network‚Äôs Elizabeth Stark, more ladies are joining in‚Äìand leading‚Äìthe conversation. bitcoin needs to take a breather. can't take a vacation when every week hits new ATHs. pic.twitter.com/mFIqDlznq5 ‚Äî Meltem Demirors (@Melt_Dem) October 31, 2017  Perhaps a piqued interest from women in Bitcoin has also been aided by wider acceptance of Bitcoin and blockchain technology by major businesses. It‚Äôs no longer an unregulated and wild space if Microsoft and JPMorgan say otherwise. Then there are more women in blockchain in general, from IBM Blockchain‚Äôs General Manager Marie Wieck to Ripple‚Äôs SVP of Corporate Development Kahina Van Dyke. Bitcoin is a gender-neutral technology with no barriers to entry nor tangible reasons why female users are still so few. However, small-but-significant steps are taken almost daily.  From Microsoft Excel adding Bitcoin as a currency option on Excel to Apple adding the B symbol to its new font set, Bitcoin is gaining mindshare in females‚Äìand the greater public at large‚Äìand that‚Äôs what really counts. Will more women continue to join the Bitcoin revolution? Share your thoughts below!

author: Anja van Oosterhout
headertext: Warren Buffett Will Face ‚ÄòAll Blockchain Leaders‚Äô At $4.6M Crypto Lunch
subheaders: ['Sun: Lunch To Bridge Crypto And Traditional Investors', 'No Shilling Tron to Warren Buffett']
contenttext: Anja van Oosterhout | Jun 11, 2019 | 04:30 Tron CEO Justin Sun will seek help from ‚Äúall the leaders‚Äù in cryptocurrency when he has lunch with infamous Bitcoin naysayer Warren Buffett. Speaking to Yahoo! Finance in an interview June 11, Sun, who paid $4.56 million in an annual charity auction to dine with Buffett, said his own project should not form the sole focus of the meeting. ‚Äú‚Ä¶We want this lunch to be a bridge between the cryptocurrency community and the traditional investor, so that‚Äôs why I will bring all the leaders in the‚Ä¶ blockchain industry‚Ä¶ to have more communication, which will benefit both sides,‚Äù he told the network.  Sun raised eyebrows when he announced his participation in the auction, which was held on eBay, earlier this month.  As Bitcoinist reported, his stance within cryptocurrency focuses heavily on publicity for the Tron platform and its associated TRX token, Sun frequently criticizing other extant networks such as altcoin leader Ethereum.  Nevertheless, the event, the date of which remains unknown, will form an interesting occasion when Buffett will be outnumbered at the negotiating table. The 88-year-old Berkshire Hathaway CEO has delivered uniquely sour verdicts on Bitcoin in recent years, variously describing it as ‚Äúrat poison squared,‚Äù a ‚Äúgambling device‚Äù and ‚Äúnot investing.‚Äù His veteran partner in crime, Berkshire vice chairman Charlie Munger, contributed ‚Äúturds‚Äù and ‚Äúfreshly harvested baby brains‚Äù to the mixture.  Sun knows he will also have his work cut out, voicing doubts about the true potential for anyone to convince Buffett that cryptocurrency is worth gaining exposure to. ‚ÄúIt might be unrealistic in just three hours to convince Warren Buffett to buy cryptocurrencies,‚Äù he said in response to a tongue-in-cheek question about using the lunch to ‚Äúshill Tron.‚Äù We just want to show him the recent progress of‚Ä¶ cryptocurrency and‚Ä¶ blockchain technology.‚Äù\ The showdown at least has time on its side: Bitcoin price 00 has rallied once again in recent days to challenge $8000, capping overall six month gains of 136 percent.  Berkshire‚Äôs own share price history ‚Äì up 127,000 percent since 1979 ‚Äì already pales in comparison to the profits of an original Bitcoin investor. Since its first recorded price in 2009, as of April this year, BTC/USD was up 720 million percent.  Sun meanwhile let slip that his own stash of crypto cash was not involved in paying for the privilege of meeting fiat royalty. The funds instead came from BitTorrent, which Tron acquired last year and which has ‚Äúnothing to do with‚Äù the crypto sector, he noted. What do you think about the outcome of Justin Sun‚Äôs lunch with Warren Buffett? Let us know in the comments below!

author: Osato Avan-Nomayo
headertext: Over 300 New Bitcoin ATMs Installed Last Month ‚Äì A Yearly High
subheaders: ['306 Bitcoin ATMs Installed in May 2019', 'Increasing Support for More Cryptocurrencies', 'Approaching the 5,000 Milestone']
contenttext: Osato Avan-Nomayo ¬∑  @3rdPesinSingula | Jun 10, 2019 | 17:00 Bitcoin ATMs saw the highest monthly increase in May 2019 for almost a year with a net growth of 228 across the globe. Data from Coinatmradar shows that the increase in bitcoin ATM installation across the globe in May 2019 reached a 1-year high. Comparing the number of machines installed and removed during the month shows net positive growth of 228.  Operators installed 306 bitcoin ATMs during the month, bumping up the number of such machines from 4,690 to 4,898. The highest ever net positive growth as recorded by Coinatmradar is still the 256 achieve in April 2018. This significant increase in crypto ATM installation in May 2019 coincides with the market‚Äôs best month so far in the year. Bitcoin, in particular, added more than $3,500 to its price in May, increasing by close to 60%. BTC‚Äôs stellar performance in May saw its year-to-date growth cross 120 percent. The top-ranked cryptocurrency has since dipped by about 10 percent after reaching a 2019 high of $9,100. According to Coinatmradar, more bitcoin kiosks offered support for other cryptocurrencies in May 2019 than in previous months. In its monthly summary report published on Thursday (June 6, 2019) the platform revealed that 69.6 percent of all machines features support for other tokens apart from BTC.  Ether (ETH) remains the most popular supported cryptocurrency after bitcoin with litecoin and bitcoin cash in second and third, respectively (as far as altcoin support is concerned). More than 150 machines added support for ETH in May 2019. As at press time, there are 4,935 crypto ATMs spread over 77 countries around the world. The United States still has the greatest number of such machines and also saw the highest number of installations in May 2019. The U.K. and Hungary had the second and third highest increase in bitcoin ATM installation for the month. Bahrain also got its first ever bitcoin ATM, currently located in Manama. Amid the continued growth of the crypto ATM market, there appears to be regulatory trouble on the horizon, especially from Canada. The country is second in the world after the United States when it comes to hosting these specialized machines. Now, city officials in Vancouver are reportedly looking to ban bitcoin ATMs. Law enforcement officials in the city say crypto kiosks are being used to for money laundering. The first ever bitcoin ATM in the world was installed in Vancouver back in 2013. Meanwhile, south of the border, Coinstar announced last month that it‚Äôs planning to expand bitcoin buying support to over 2,200 location across the U.S. after a successful trial. Though, it should be noted that these aren‚Äôt counted in as specialized ‚Äòbitcoin ATMs‚Äô by CoinATMRadar. Do you think the increasing number of bitcoin ATMs will make cryptocurrencies more mainstream? Let us know in the comments below.

author: Christina Comben
headertext: ‚Äò2019 Is the New 2017‚Äô for Bitcoin, Says Crypto ‚ÄòWunderkind‚Äô
subheaders: ['Bitcoin and Blockchain Are the Cutting Edge', 'But 2019 Is Definitely Not the New 2017']
contenttext: Christina Comben | Jun 10, 2019 | 14:00 Orange is the new black. Male stockings are all the rage. And 2019 is the new 2017, according to Bitcoin millionaire and ‚Äòwunderkind‚Äô Erik Finman. Erik Finman. If that name rings a bell, it‚Äôs probably for one of a few reasons. It could be because of his extremely large fortune accumulated by buying bitcoin in 2011. Or, it could be for his equally large ego.  Finman was never backward in coming forward about his riches, staging plenty of gaudy pictures on his Instagram account.   Icons like me üòòüíÖwill always be hated. bc we are the immortals. just wait till what‚Äôs next. A post shared by  ERIK FIN (@erikfinman) on Jul 28, 2018 at 11:56am PDT  If that doesn‚Äôt jog your memory, it may be because he came out with a woefully wrong prediction last December that Bitcoin was dead and Litecoin was breathing its last breaths. Just a few days later, both markets began to sprint with Litecoin making gains of over 250 percent. If you still haven‚Äôt got this now 20-year-old ‚Äòwunderkind‚Äô down, perhaps it‚Äôs because you‚Äôre using his ‚Äúrevolutionary‚Äù new app CoinBits. Although, that‚Äôs rather doubtful since a rehash of a four-year-old investment app using dollar-cost averaging is hardly revolutionary and it has just a handful of users. However you‚Äôve heard of the now post-pubescent Bitcoin messiah, he‚Äôs rebranding himself and moving away from his tragic predictions of 2018. That was so last year, after all. Finman is switching up the dark glasses and suit for some nerdy specs and a T-shirt and positioning himself as a thought leader in the space, presumably with a very expensive PR agency behind him. It turns out that Bitcoin and blockchain are back in fashion and ‚Äúcutting edge‚Äù after all. While Finman makes soundbite statements like this and enthuses that products like his will ‚Äòresurrect‚Äô the Bitcoin price back to $20k by the end of the year, it‚Äôs hard not to roll your eyes. After all, Finman‚Äôs knowledge of Bitcoin goes back to 2011. If anyone should know better about the cryptocurrency space, it‚Äôs him. And 2019 is definitely not the new 2017. Far from it, in fact; a lot has changed over the last two years. To start with, expectations have been adjusted from the mania days, in which blockchain could cure cancer and geeks with too much money were busy spending their college funds on CryptoKitties. Bitcoin is way better placed than ever it was during the height of retail FOMO. Transactions, hash rate, usage, and average block size are all well up from 2017 despite the long bear market. There‚Äôs a ton more fiat on-ramps, proven use cases, more Bitcoin ATMs, fewer scams, institutional investment, major names like Microsoft, eBay, and Apple on board. Even the SEC has decided that Bitcoin is not a security.  So, change your image all you want Mr. Finman. But save us these trite soundbites, particularly after you declared Bitcoin dead. Oh, and, please stop this desperate bid to align yourself with big brand names like Facebook, AT&T, and Andrew Yang‚Äìno matter how much your PR agency insists. Do you agree that 2019 is shaping up to be like 2017? Add your thoughts below!

author: Emilio Janus
headertext: ‚ÄòTrojan Horse For Bitcoin‚Äô and 5 Other Predictions For Facebook‚Äôs Crypto
subheaders: ['1. It Will Be A Force For Good In Developing Countries', '2. Facebook Will Pay Interest To Holders Of Libra', '3. Facebooks Foundation Will Garner Big Power In Capital Markets', '4. The Project Will Face Regulatory Uncertainty', '5. Questions Will Be Asked', '6. Libra Will Turn Out To Be A Trojan Horse For Bitcoin']
contenttext: Emilio Janus | Jun 10, 2019 | 12:00 Wyoming cryptocurrency advocate, Caitlin Long, has been sharing her predictions for Facebook‚Äôs forthcoming ‚ÄòLibra‚Äô explaining why it may be a ‚Äòtrojan horse‚Äô for Bitcoin. The coin, now known as ‚ÄòLibra‚Äô (and no longer GlobalCoin as first believed), is expected to launch on 18th June. So what does Long predict? 1/ 6 PREDICTIONS about what @Facebook's #cryptocurrency means. Grab the popcorn bc I analyzed publicly disclosed info to make 6 predictions, of which 2 will be controversial (#2 and #6). @ForbesCrypto #Libra #bitcoin https://t.co/6EI55eyvUA ‚Äî Caitlin Long üîë (@CaitlinLong_) June 9, 2019  Libra will be aggressively marketed in developing nations with more volatile fiat currencies. Long highlights Venezuela as the most visible example, and says: By providing citizens of developing nations with access to a store-of-value that is more reliable than their government-backed currencies, Facebook‚Äôs cryptocurrency will indirectly exert fiscal and monetary discipline on developing nations‚Äîwhich will improve the lives of many people globally. Long believes that Facebook will face a backlash from users if it does not share interest income from the assets backing the cryptocurrency. Although most stablecoins ‚Äòpocket the float‚Äô, Libra will likely be too big and visible to get away with this. This could also highlight the level of corporate subsidies from the Fed to U.S. banks, leading to calls to repeal them. Facebook plans to hand over control of Libra to an independent foundation, which it formed in Switzerland. This foundation is likely to become powerful in global capital markets, as it will do what central banks do. It will define the relative weighting of the fiat currencies to which Libra is pegged, and manage the assets.  This is a positive thing, as it will highlight how ill-suited existing regulations are to cryptocurrency. Long also ponders: Will Facebook catch breaks from regulators that smaller start-ups haven‚Äôt‚Äîbecause of the tax data honeypot Facebook‚Äôs project will generate for governments? Either way, it should bring more clarity to the rest of the cryptocurrency space. Facebook plans to apply more stringent forms of KYC and AML than most cryptocurrencies. This would lead to the aforementioned ‚Äòtax data honeypot‚Äô, as governments would be very keen to trace every dollar spent by their citizens. Not that Facebook will necessarily agree to provide it. However, not having the greatest track record when it comes to data security, Facebook will be the topic of many discussions now its corporate power will extend to money. Facebook‚Äôs cryptocurrency will greatly accelerate interest and education in the sector. However, Long thinks that this is just a welcome detour on the way to increased Bitcoin adoption. Bitcoin is scarce, while Facebook‚Äôs cryptocurrency is not. People will migrate over time to the most honest ledger for storing their hard-earned wealth‚Äîand that‚Äôs not fiat currencies or derivatives thereof, including Facebook‚Äôs cryptocurrency. The same happened in Venezuela; when Maduro tried to educate people to support the Petro, they ended up gravitating towards bitcoin. Do you agree with these predictions for Facebook‚Äôs crypto? Add your thoughts below!

author: Anja van Oosterhout
headertext: Bitcoin Analysts Divided on Chance Of Parabolic Advance Over $9k
subheaders: ['Demeester: 2019 is 2012 Repeat', 'BTC Price Phase Or Fail?']
contenttext: Anja van Oosterhout | Jun 10, 2019 | 07:00 Bitcoin price was causing mixed feelings June 9 as continued sideways trading put an end to hopes of another parabolic advance. Data from cryptocurrency exchange Bitstamp‚Äôs generally more conservative price tracker put BTC/USD at $7720 as of press time Monday.  The pair had had a rocky weekend‚Äôs trading, losing around 9 percent since Friday and bottoming out at $7533. 24-hour losses totaled 2.7%, while monthly performance remains stronger at 14.4% gains.  Bitcoin price 00 retracement after hitting $9000 has nonetheless instilled caution in analysts. Tuur Demeester, founding partner at Adamant Capital and a regulator Bitcoin commentator, noted BTC/USD had broken a key trendline last week, having already sounded the alarm about a new downturn.  ‚ÄúShould $9,000 prove the top (which is not a given) and if then we‚Äôd see a 2012-style correction repeated, we would expect after an initial crash to see bitcoin trade in a range between $6,800 and $7,680 (27‚Äì44% retrace of the rally),‚Äù he wrote in a blog post June 5.   For Demeester, a key aspect of this year‚Äôs Bitcoin price rally is its similarity to a previous bull cycle in 2012.  This time around, however, increased market maturity is resulting in differing qualities, but ‚Äúexcessive short term optimism‚Äù remains a factor.  ‚ÄúIn our opinion, and as Peter Brandt argues, for this bull market to continue at a healthier pace we need for the FOMO to subside, which will likely happen via a violent correction,‚Äù he concluded.  After that, we could for a few months see bitcoin trade in a range with lows that are 25% below whatever the high this parabolic curve will produce. As Bitcoinist reported, Brandt had himself appeared overly optimistic at the end of May, saying he felt ‚Äúcomfortable‚Äù getting exposure to Bitcoin again as the cryptocurrency traded around $8400. John Bollinger meanwhile warned Bitcoin traders to ‚Äúpay attention‚Äù at the beginning of June as uncertainty in markets continued, highlighting the possibility of an up to 50% correction.  Even now, however, not everyone is pessimistic. For the social media trader known as Rhythm, the current wavering simply marks the brooding phase of a parabolic trend, something similar to Bitcoin‚Äôs 2017 performance.  ‚ÄúThis $BTC parabolic rise is still on-going and has yet to break,‚Äù he summarized Monday. Earlier today, Bitconist noted that BTC price has recorded the biggest weekly loss since December 2018. What do you think about the short-term outlook for Bitcoin price? Let us know in the comments below!
